title: Publications
text:
Discovery of New Markers for Haemogenic Endothelium and Haematopoietic Progenitors in the Mouse Yolk Sac
Diez-Pinel, G., Muratore, A., Ruhrberg, C., & Canu, G. (2026). Discovery of New Markers for Haemogenic Endothelium and Haematopoietic Progenitors in the Mouse Yolk Sac. Journal of Developmental Biology, 14(1), 4. https://doi.org/10.3390/jdb14010004
Erythro-myeloid progenitors (EMPs) originate from the haemogenic endothelium in the yolk sac via an endothelial-to-haematopoietic transition (EHT) to generate blood and immune cells that support embryo development. They are also give rise to self-renewing tissue-resident macrophages that persist into adulthood.
I analysed a single-cell RNA sequencing datasets from mouse embryos to identify novel cell surface markers of haemogenic endothelium (Fxyd5 and Scarf1) and EMPs (Fcer1g, Tyrobp, and Mctp1). Further, I identified candidate signalling and metabolic pathways that may regulate yolk sac haematopoietic emergence and differentiation. These insights into the transcriptional dynamics in the yolk sac should support future investigation of EHT and haematopoietic differentiation during early mammalian development.




Endothelial transcriptomic, epigenomic and proteomic data challenge the proposed role for TSAd in vascular permeability
Brash, J.T., Diez-Pinel, G., Rinaldi, L. et al. Endothelial transcriptomic, epigenomic and proteomic data challenge the proposed role for TSAd in vascular permeability. Angiogenesis 28, 21 (2025). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10456-025-09971-x
The vascular endothelial growth factor VEGF drives excessive vascular permeability causing tissue-damaging oedema in neovascular and inflammatory diseases. Several molecular pathways have been implicated in VEGF-induced hyperpermeability, including binding of the receptor VEGFR2 by the T-cell specific adaptor (TSAd) to recruit a SRC family kinase to induce junction opening between vascular endothelial cells (ECs).
We have mined publicly available omics data (bulk and single-cell RNA-sequencing, proteomics, epigenomics) for expression of TSAd and other permeability-relevant signal transducers in multiple organs affected by VEGF-induced vascular permeability. TSAd protein and transcripts were largely undetected or expressed at extremely low levels in all datasets analysed, inconsistent with a universal role for TSAd in permeability signalling.





The BulkECexplorer compiles endothelial bulk transcriptomes to predict functional versus leaky transcription
Brash, J.T., Diez-Pinel, G., Colletto, C. et al. The BulkECexplorer compiles endothelial bulk transcriptomes to predict functional versus leaky transcription. Nat Cardiovasc Res 3, 460–473 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s44161-024-00436-w
RNA-seq experiments may detect lowly expressed mRNAs thought to be biologically irrelevant products of leaky transcription. To represent the functional transcriptome of endothelial cells (ECs) more accurately, we propose compiling many EC bulk RNA-seq datasets into a compendium and applying established classification models to predict whether detected transcripts are likely products of active or leaky transcription.

The BulkECexplorer web application can be used to query any protein-coding gene and generate informative dashboards combining transcriptomic data from 240 mouse and human EC samples in seconds. These samples include 5 EC subtypes commonly used in vascular biology research: HUVECs and HDMECs (human); lung, brain and retina ECs (mouse).



Endothelial Cell RNA-Seq Data: Differential Expression and Functional Enrichment Analyses to Study Phenotypic Switching
Diez-Pinel, G. Horder J. L. et al. (2022). Endothelial Cell RNA-Seq Data: Differential Expression and Functional Enrichment Analyses to Study Phenotypic Switching. In: Benest, A.V. (eds) Angiogenesis. Methods in Molecular Biology, vol 2441. Humana, New York, NY. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-0716-2059-5_29
RNA-seq is a common approach used to explore gene expression data between experimental conditions or cell types and ultimately leads to information that can shed light on the biological processes involved and inform further hypotheses.
We wrote a user-friendly bioinformatics workflow which describes the methods required to take raw data produced by RNA sequencing to interpretable results.





A Pax3 lineage gives rise to transient haematopoietic progenitors
Giovanni Canu, Rosamaria Correra, Guillermo Diez-Pinel, Raphaël F. P. Castellan, Laura Denti, Alessandro Fantin, Christiana Ruhrberg; A Pax3 lineage gives rise to transient haematopoietic progenitors. Development 1 December 2024; 151 (23): dev202924. doi: https://doi.org/10.1242/dev.202924
During embryonic development, muscle tissues, skin, and a subset of vascular endothelial cells arise from Pax3-expressing embryonic progenitors defined as paraxial mesoderm.
To determine whether the haematopoietic system also contains Pax3 lineage cells (cells that express Pax3, or whose progenitors expressed Pax3 at any point in the past), I analysed a bulk RNA-seq dataset of Pax3-derived cells from embryonic day 12.5 mouse limbs. I found that, apart from expression of expected musculoskeletal and endothelial markers, transcripts typical of haematopoietic progenitors (e.g. Kit, Vav1, Runx1) were also present.
The finding suggests that a Pax3 lineage may give rise to a subset of haematopoietic cells. Pax3 lineage haematopoietic cells should be investigated to better understand normal haematopoietic development from different mesodermal derivatives. Further, genetic alterations of Pax3 lineage haematopoietic cells should be investigated for their potential to cause haematopoietic malignancies.

title: Guillermo’s Portfolio
text:
I am a bioinformatician with a strong interest in human health, software development and project management. Experienced in R and analysis of omics data, always eager to learn the tools and write the code needed to research and fight disease.
As a postdoctoral researcher in Christiana Ruhrberg’s lab at UCL, I analyse bulk and single-cell RNAseq data from patients with peripheral artery disease and from mouse models that reproduce this disease. This work is funded by the Leducq Foundation and by the British Heart Foundation.
In this website, you can find links to my repositories, which contain code to easily run and automate various transcriptomic analyses, source code from my Shiny apps, and others. On the publications page you can find information about my scientific articles.

title: Guillermo’s Portfolio
text:
Repositories

runDESeq2
https://github.com/g-pinel/runDESeq2

Bulk RNA-seq experiments often include many samples belonging to multiple experimental groups and involve performing multiple comparisons between different subsets of these samples.
The functions in this repository allow you to run one or multiple pairwise differential expression analyses using the R DESeq2 package.


runEnrichmentAnalyses
https://github.com/g-pinel/runEnrichmentAnalyses

After performing differential expression analyses to obtain a list of differentially-expressed genes (DEGs), it is common to run enrichment analyses to identify groups of genes that participate in the same process or pathway and are enriched in one of the groups being compared.
The functions in this repository allow you to easily run enrichment analyses in R against the Gene Ontology, KEGG, Wiki Pathways and Reactome databases using DESeq2’s DeseqDataSet (DDS) objects as inputs.


autoGSEApreranked
https://github.com/g-pinel/autoGSEApreranked

GSEA (Gene Set Enrichment Analysis) is a software used to determine whether a group of genes shows differences between two biological states (e.g. treatment versus control, high versus low drug dose). In this type of analysis, all genes expressed by the input samples are sorted from those most enriched in one condition to those most enriched in the other, generating a ranked list. Then, specific groups of genes are tested against this ranked list to identify those gene sets that are enriched in one of the biological states.
However, standard GSEA analyses do not support controlling for covariates like sex and age. To overcome this, you can supply GSEA with your own ranked list of genes (GSEA Preranked). Differential expression analysis packages like R’s DESeq2, allow to control for covariates, and the test statistic that they output can be used as the ranking metric for the resulting genes.
The scripts in this repository allows you to easily generate the RNK files needed to run GSEA preranked by supplying DESeq2 objects (as RDS files) or results tables (as CSV files). You can do this in batch for multiple input files. In addition, scripts for running one or multiple GSEA preranked analyses with a single command is also provided. You can use the RNK files obtained with the code in this repository, or provide your own.
You can find more information about GSEA here.


qPCR analyzer
https://github.com/g-pinel/qPCR-analyzer

Process your qRT-PCR data generated using QuantStudio with a single command. Simply provide your QuantStudio output excel files to obtain CTs, delta CTs, and levels (2-ΔCt).  Both XLS and XLSX supported, as well as combining multiple files from the same project.
